I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The first energy policy1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) was prepared in 1981 and 
the second policy2 paper was published in 1995. The energy policy was reviewed in 20003 and 
recommended four operational priorities: (i) reduce poverty by creating energy infrastructure for 
sustainable economic growth and increasing access to energy for the poor, particularly in rural 
areas; (ii) promote private sector involvement by restructuring the energy sector and creating an 
enabling environment for private investors; (iii) addressing regional and/or global environmental 
impacts,  especially  acid  rain  problems,  supporting  clean  energy  and  the  Kyoto  Protocol 
mechanisms for greenhouse gas abatement, and financing renewable energy projects; and (iv) 
promoting regional cooperation. The 2000 review further recommended that the Energy Policy be 
reviewed after 5 years. 
 
2.  According  to  some  recently  published  international  reports, 4  the  world’s  energy 
consumption has reached unsustainable levels. Increased economic growth has encouraged 
increased energy consumption, especially fossil fuels, resulting in increased greenhouse gas 
generation. The effects of such consumption has resulted in harmful effects on the climate, such 
as an increase in the earth’s temperature and abnormal climatic conditions. It was considered by 
ADB Management that ADB should assess its energy sector operations to realign its energy 
strategy to address the needs of its developing member countries (DMCs) in a more sustainable 
way and encourage clean energy development. ADB’s Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department’s (RSDD) Energy, Transport, and Water Division (RSID) initiated a review5 of ADB’s 
energy operations to evaluate previous operations, examine the relevance of the current energy 
policies, and prepare a new strategy that will address the emerging needs of DMCs. A draft paper 
was prepared by RSID and reviewed by the Energy Community of Practice (CoP) in January 
2007. The paper is currently being revised and will be circulated for interdepartmental comments 
in March 2007. The Operations Evaluation Department (OED) is currently conducting a parallel 
evaluation of ADB’s energy sector operations. OED’s recommendations will feed into the new 
strategy as appropriate. 
 
3.  The revised energy policy is being developed within the framework of the existing policy, 
which continues to be robust and relevant. Nevertheless, a focused approach is needed to 
address the tremendous increase in energy demand in Asia and the effects of unsustainable 
energy consumption on the environment. Accordingly, RSDD designed the Clean Energy and 
Environment Program (CEEP), which is a comprehensive strategic program to assist DMCs 
achieve measurable changes in their energy use pattern and secure a low carbon sustainable 
energy future. The program covers a number of specific initiatives, such as the ongoing multi-
donor-funded Renewable Energy, Energy Efficiency, and Climate Change (REACH), the Energy 
Efficiency Initiative (EEI), the Carbon Market Initiative (CMI), Energy for All, Energy Efficiency in 
Transport, and Development of Knowledge Hubs. The proposed energy strategy will encompass 
these initiatives within its framework and propose a way forward for ADB and its DMCs.

4.  According to ADB’s Public Communications Policy6 and Staff Guide to Consultation and 
Participation,7 ADB should seek the active participation of its shareholders and other interested 
individuals  and  organizations  during  the  development  and  review  of  its  thematic  strategies 
(Component  1).  Therefore,  the  first  component  of  this  TA  is  to  finance  the  stakeholder 
consultation process for the energy strategy. Second, building on the success of last year’s Clean 
Energy Week, it is proposed to organize a Clean Energy Forum as a sub-event of the proposed 
Asia-Pacific  Sustainable  Development  Summit  (Component  2).  This  will  be  a  forum  for 
disseminating  the  new  energy  strategy  and  consultations  on  moving  forward  with  the  new 
initiatives. Further, it is proposed to publish a number of technical papers of current relevance 
(knowledge products) (Component 3) that will be disseminated among ADB and DMC staff for 
easy reference on key issues. The scope and direction of the proposed technical assistance 
(TA)8 grant for the Energy Sector Strategy and Development Program 2007 was defined in the 
concept paper cleared by Management in July 2006. This TA is included in the core TA program 
of RSDD for 2007. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  For ADB to be effective and relevant, it must work together with a broad spectrum of 
people  and  organizations.  Strong  partnerships  have  to  be  created  with  a  broad  range  of 
stakeholders  and  civil  society  organizations  (CSOs).  Information  sharing  is  essential  to 
participatory  development,  and  ADB  must  demonstrate  openness  and  accountability  by 
proactively sharing information with, and seeking suggestions and feedback, from stakeholders—
especially when preparing an important strategic document such as the energy strategy. Global 
warming and climate change are contentious issues, which, coupled with the need for energy 
security,  have  far-reaching  ramifications  and  attract  worldwide  interest.  Consultations,  both 
external and internal, are important so that concerns of relevant key stakeholders are taken into 
account  while  preparing  the  strategy.  Further,  ADB  will  benefit  from  the  knowledge  and 
experience gained from such consultations, which will enhance the quality of the strategy. 
   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The main impact of this regional TA will be improved sustainable supply of energy. 
 
7.  The intended outcome of this TA will be increased support for ADB’s energy sector 
operations from a range of stakeholders and experts. In addition, the TA will provide stakeholders 
with comprehensive updates on recent energy issues, policy requirements, and energy outlook 
for the region.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Component 1: Consultation and Participation 
8.  The consultation process is designed to be implemented in three steps. The first step, 
which has been completed, included interaction with DMC governments, executing agencies, 
energy utilities, CSOs, educational institutions, multilateral and bilateral funding agencies, and 
energy research institutes. Based on these consultations and further in-depth analysis, a draft 
strategy has been developed. This draft will be discussed within ADB through interdepartmental 
and management reviews and an informal ADB’s Board of Directors seminar. Staff Instructions 
and the Staff Guide to Consultation and Participation (footnote 7) recommend that ADB should 
undergo consultations with external stakeholders through direct interaction and electronic media. 
These will be carried out after review of the draft strategy and consent of the Management 
Committee, and will be implemented through regional workshops and electronic consultations. 
Participants will be selected after consultations with operations departments. Therefore, in the 
second stage, three regional workshops will be held. Online consultations via the energy strategy 
website and e-mail, as well as external consultations with experts, will run in parallel with the 
various workshops. In the third stage, the approved energy strategy will be posted on the ADB 
website for information. Printed booklets will be distributed through ADB’s Public Information 
Center. 
 
2.  Component  2:  Clean  Energy  Forum  of  the  Asia-Pacific  Sustainable 
Development Summit 
 
9.  The Clean Energy Forum will build on the success of the 2006 Clean Energy Week, which 
provided  a  unique  opportunity  for  DMCs’  clients,  donor  governments,  CSOs,  and  other 
stakeholders of the region to interact and exchange lessons learned in the energy sector. In 
addition, at the 2006 Clean Energy Week, ADB benefited from the active participation and expert 
guidance from a number of participants on the needs of the region and recommendations on how 
ADB’s Energy Strategy should be realigned. The Clean Energy Forum will continue to focus on 
clean energy, energy security, and sustainable development—with special focus on energy for all 
and  private  participation  in  clean  energy  development.  Participants  will  be  selected  after 
consultations with operations departments. The timing for the event is important for ADB. This 
forum will be an ideal setting for disseminating ADB’s energy strategy and to seek cooperation 
and consultations on the implementation of the various initiatives. ADB will also collaborate with 
other  development  agencies  such  as  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development 
(USAID) in organizing a forum on clean energy financing workshop under USAID’s Eco Asian 
Clean Development and Climate Program. The French Development Agency (AFD) has indicated 
interest in participating and has proposed to sponsor speakers on regulatory mechanism for 
energy efficiency and new technologies. 
 
3.  Component 3: Knowledge Products–Technical Notes 
10.  The Asia and Pacific region is experiencing rapid economic growth, resulting in increased 
energy demand. According to estimates released by the International Energy Agency,9 total world 
energy demand is expected to grow from 7,261 million tons of oil equivalent (mtoe) in 2004 to 
17,095 mtoe in 2030. As far as the electricity sector is concerned, coal-based power generation 
will account for about 80% of total electricity generation in 2030. Most of this increased demand 
will be in the People’s Republic of China and India, with some increased demand in other 
                                                 
9  IEA. 2006. World Energy Outlook 2006. Paris.

4   
emerging  economies  such  as  Indonesia  and  Viet Nam.  Such  increased  use  of  coal  has 
unsustainable effects on the climate. Carbon dioxide emissions have already reached high levels 
and their effect on the climate is obvious. Some of these effects are abnormal weather patterns 
experienced  recently,  such  as  intense  storms,  severe  and  frequent  droughts  and  floods, 
accelerated melting of glaciers, rise in sea level, higher frequency of forest fires, shortage of 
freshwater, threatened crop production and aquaculture, and higher incidence of heat-related and 
infectious diseases. Hence, there is a need to utilize coal in a more sustainable and efficient 
manner. Various cleaner technologies have been developed and some are in the process of 
development. The key issue will be to facilitate the path of technology transfer that is beneficial to 
all stakeholders. Initially, it is proposed to commission a technical paper that highlights the effects 
of  coal-based  power  generation,  its  economies,  need  for  new  technologies,  time  frame  for 
development, prospects of technology transfer, research costs, government policies and options 
for facilitating such transfer, and how multilateral agencies can help. Subsequent technical notes 
will focus on further development of zero-carbon technologies, and energy efficiency. 
 
11.  For a sustained and transparent electricity market, strict and fair regulatory mechanisms 
need to be in place as part of a phased reform and restructuring of the sector. Private sector 
participation will also increase to meet growth in demand. In Asia, results of power sector reforms 
have been mixed—partially successful in some, and unsuccessful in others. It is clear that “one-
size-fits–all” is not the right approach. Therefore, there is a need to provide DMCs with a history 
of the reforms, its development over time, costs, social and legal issues, lessons learned with 
case studies, and a list of options to achieve a transparent and fair electricity market that will 
focus on the benefits of the consumer. RSID will collaborate with other departments involved in 
governance—especially the Office of the General Counsel (OGC) which is coordinating and 
collaborating with RSID on various energy regulation projects. It is intended that issues identified 
and discussed in this paper will be further developed and researched under OGC’s energy 
regulation knowledge products. 
 
12.  Advances in economic growth and associated increased energy demand have resulted in 
huge investments in the energy sector. Growth potential is huge and DMCs are addressing 
increased  energy  needs  with  a  variety  of  approaches,  including  technology  transfer  and 
innovative financing. Nevertheless, about 1 billion people in the Asia and Pacific region continue 
to live without access to modern forms of energy. Many DMCs have successfully embarked on 
addressing this important social need with some success but much more needs to be done if the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) are to be achieved. It has been established that modern 
energy access, though not identified as an MDG, will contribute to the achievement of almost all 
the MDG goals. A number of options are being explored, such as grid extensions and off-grid 
systems.  In  such  cases,  the  option  of  community-based  organization  setting  up  their  own 
distributed off-grid system could be sustained, and needs to be explored.  
13.  Taking the above aspects into consideration, ADB proposes to publish technical notes 
that will be made available to ADB and DMCs as knowledge products. These will be prepared by 
ADB along with experts or through energy research centers. Condensed versions will be included 
as part of the forthcoming publication on Energy Outlook and Data Book 2007 for the Asia and 
Pacific Region. In 2007, it is initially proposed to cover the following topics: 
(i)  Low  Carbon Emitting Technologies in Electricity Generation – Options and 
Future Outlook 
(ii)  Power Sector Regulation – Lessons Learned and The Way Forward 
(iii)  Community-Based Distributed Power Generation

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the regional TA, estimated at $400,000, will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s TA funding program. The TA cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  various  components  of  the  TA  will  be  implemented  separately  according  to 
requirements and schedule starting April 2007, and will be completed by June 2008. ADB, 
through RSDD/RSID, will serve as the Executing Agency. No specific DMC has been identified to 
undertake the activities of the regional TA. However, any activity funded by this regional TA will 
only commence in a particular DMC after ADB has obtained a no-objection letter from the 
respective government as to inclusion of such DMC in the regional TA. 
1.  Consultation and Participation 
16.  Three  subregional  stakeholder  consultations  and/or  workshops  will  be  conducted  in 
selected key DMCs (to be determined). One international consultant, a consultative process 
facilitator, will be recruited for 4 person-months. A national consultation workshop coordinator will 
be recruited for research and workshop coordination support for 5 person-months. Mission travel 
will be required for consultants to the selected countries for subregional consultation workshops. 
Terms  of  reference  for  the  international  and  national  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
consultants will be recruited as individuals in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time).
 
2.   Clean Energy Forum of the Asia-Pacific Sustainable Development Summit 
17.  The Clean Energy Forum will be held in ADB headquarters as a sub-event under the 
proposed Asia-Pacific Sustainable Development Summit in November 2007. The TA will finance 
the expenses of some of the DMC officials, civil society, speakers, and other participants; and 
also include other workshop expenses (materials, handouts, snacks, cocktail reception, and other 
services). One national event coordinator will be recruited for 3 months in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants to assist RSDD in organizing the workshop.  
 
3.  Knowledge Products  
18.  Three  well-known  international  experts  or  reputed  energy  research  centers  will  be 
assigned  to  develop  high  quality  technical  papers  which  will  be  sent  to  peer  reviewers  for 
comments  and  guidance  before  publication  and  dissemination.  These  consultants  will  be 
recruited for a period of about 2 months each in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
the Energy Sector Strategy and Development 2007 and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultant, Consultative Process Facilitator (4 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
1.   Background and Objective 
 
1.  In this case, consultations will be internal and external (with governments, development 
partners, and civil society—including civil society organizations [CSOs]), private sector, academia, 
and donor agencies. In addition, well-known experts will be requested to provide peer review. 
 
2.  The  consultations  will  be  complex,  involving  agencies  and  institutions  with  different 
perspectives as well as diverse development interests and objectives. However, it is recognized 
that the groups share an interest in ensuring that development projects financed by ADB avoid or 
minimize adverse impacts, and that mitigation measures are developed and agreed upon with 
stakeholders,  especially  affected  persons.  External  consultations  will  involve  governments  of 
developed and developing countries, CSOs, academia, research institutions, workers and business 
representatives, multilateral and bilateral aid agencies, and institutions that are closely involved in 
processing and implementing ADB-financed projects. The consultations will include private sector 
representatives who are involved in ADB-financed projects either directly or through financial 
intermediaries. 
 
2.   Scope of Work 
 
3.  The  facilitator  will  ensure  the  smooth  organization  and  implementation  of  the  regional 
consultations,  and  any  other  meetings  that  may  be  required.  The  facilitator  will  accurately 
document  the  outcomes  of  the  meetings  and  the  positions  of  the  participants,  particularly 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and CSOs representatives. The facilitator will help review 
exchanges and respond to queries raised by participants and civil society representatives. 
 
4.  The facilitator will have some exposure to current and emerging energy sector issues in 
developing member countries (DMCs) and international financial institutions. The facilitator should 
be familiar with the role, functions, and operations of multilateral agencies such as ADB; and will 
preferably be involved in multilateral development and NGO-related activities, either as a member 
of a CSO or as a holder of a position that requires interaction with such organizations. The position 
also requires the following: 
 
(i)   experience in public consultation and participatory practices; 
(ii)   interpersonal skills required to deal with complex negotiating situations; 
(iii)  very good verbal and written English language skills; and 
(iv)   an understanding of cultural, government, and institutional conditions in the Asia 
and Pacific region. 
 
3.   Detailed Tasks 
 
5.  Specific tasks assigned to the facilitator will include, but will not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  developing a detailed work plan for the consultative process, and preparing suitable 
lists of participants in collaboration with operations departments; 
(ii)  designing and implementing internal and external consultation processes, including 
tasks such as helping prepare workshop-related materials, maintaining a database 
to  record  responses  received,  making  arrangements  with  resident  missions,

10  Appendix 3 
 
acknowledging all responses received, and performing other tasks as directed by 
the team leader; 
(iii)  participating in selected workshops as directed by the team leader; 
(iv)   compiling, analyzing, and reporting on each workshop and on the cumulative results 
of all workshops; 
(v)   preparing reports that identify comments received internally and externally, and 
explaining how they were addressed; 
(vi)  managing and updating the energy strategy website; 
(vii)  scheduling the consultation and participation process; 
(viii)  preparing FAQs for the website; 
(ix)  responding to questions; and 
(x)  preparing and submitting a formal report on the consultation process. 
 
4.    Reporting Requirements and Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  The assignment will be based partly in Manila, Philippines, and will require travel to DMCs 
as determined by the team leader as part of the consultative process for the development of the 
energy  strategy.  The  assignment  is  expected  to  be  for  4  person-months  intermittently  over 
6 months, starting in April 2007. 
 
7.  The facilitator will be accountable to the ADB team leader under the overall guidance of the 
Director of ADB’s Regional Sustainable Development Department’s (RSDD) Energy, Transport, 
and Water Division (RSID). 
 
B.  National Consultant, Consultation Workshop Coordinator (5 person-months) 
 
1.   Background and Objective 
 
8.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  the  services  of  a  consultation  workshop 
coordinator,  who  will  support  the  consultative  process  and  provide  general  assistance  in 
consultation for and dissemination of the energy strategy. 
 
2.   Scope of Work 
 
9.  The  consultant  will  ensure  the  smooth  conduct  of  consultations  and  update  activities, 
including  organizational  arrangements,  logistics,  documentation,  and  outreach.  Participation  in 
country and regional consultations, and any other meetings as decided by the team leader, may be 
required. The consultant will work closely with the facilitator, who will lead the consultative process. 
 
10.  The consultant will have exposure to organizing and managing international workshops. 
The consultant should be familiar with the role, functions, and operations of multilateral agencies 
such as ADB, and will preferably have been involved in multilateral development activities. The 
position requires the following: 
 
(i)  extensive experience in planning and organizing international workshops; 
(ii)  interpersonal skills required to deal with complex cross-cultural situations;  
(iii)  ability to work independently and achieve timely outputs; and 
(iv)   very good verbal and written English skills.

3.   Detailed Tasks 
 
11.  Specific tasks assigned to the communication specialist will include, but not be limited to, 
the following: 
 
(i)  arranging  and  conducting  internal  and  external  consultations,  assisting  in 
documentation (including workshop materials), setting up participants’ database, 
and producing reports and publications; 
(ii)  ensuring  that  all  logistical  arrangements  are set  up  in  a  timely  manner  and in 
accordance  with  existing  ADB  protocols,  which  will  include  facilitating  travel  of 
workshop participants; 
(iii)  coordinating with relevant officers in ADB headquarters and resident missions; 
(iv)  participating in selected workshops as directed by the team leader;  
(v)  compiling, analyzing, and reporting on key events and background papers;  
(vi)  preparing  postworkshop  reports  and  outputs,  which  include  a  final  report  on 
workshop expenses; and  
(vii)   any other tasks as assigned by the team leader. 
 
4.   Reporting Requirements and Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The assignment will be based in Manila, Philippines, and will require travel to DMCs as 
determined by the ADB team leader as part of the consultative process for the safeguard policy 
update. The assignment will be for 5 person-months, full time, starting April 2007. 
 
C.  Resource Speakers, Moderators, and Discussants 
 
13.  The speakers, moderators, and discussants to be invited to Clean Energy Week 2007 will 
be prominent regional and global experts recognized for innovative thinking and leadership in the 
field of development, poverty reduction, and clean energy. They will be engaged as resource 
persons,  and  will  be  asked  to  deliver  keynote  addresses  and/or  sit  as  panel  discussants  in 
roundtable discussions during the event. 
 
D.  National Consultant, Event Coordinator (3 person-months) 
14.  The consultant should have solid experience in organizing and coordinating large events 
and/or workshops and possess basic management skills necessary to successfully organize and 
coordinate such events. He/she will carry out the work in close consultation with the RSID energy 
specialist since the event will be carried out in coordination with other ADB offices and resident 
country missions, such as the proposed Asia-Pacific Sustainable Development Summit 2007. The 
consultant will need to coordinate with relevant staff on the detailed arrangements.  
15.  The consultant will ensure the efficient planning, implementation, and documentation of the 
conduct of the regional consultations, scheduled to be held in 2007. The tasks of the consultant will 
include, but will not be limited to, the following:  
 
(i)  Coordinate all logistical arrangements for the workshop, including all arrangements 
necessary for participants’ and resource persons’ travel. 
(ii)  Draft and send invitation letters to internal and external participants, respond to 
inquiries, and liaise with international and regional experts and resident missions (if 
needed) to confirm attendance. 
(iii)  Assist in identifying and engaging suitable resource persons, and provide support to 
resource persons, as required, to execute the workshop. 
(iv)  Participate in and document pre-workshop meetings, if any.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  Coordinate and set up workable arrangements with resident missions concerned 
with  regard  to  funds  transfer  to  imprest  account  for  participants’  travel-related 
expenses. 
(vi)  Liaise with ADB’s Department of External Relations (DER) to ensure the event is 
covered by international media services through the ADB Media Center, and within 
ADB (ADB Today and ADB website announcements). 
(vii)  Facilitate relevant protocols for the event. 
(viii)  Compile workshop materials, including PowerPoint presentations and handouts, and 
liaise with ADB’s Printing Office for the production of workshop materials. 
(ix)  Provide and coordinate secretariat support during and after the workshop, including 
disbursement of per diem to participants and liquidation of expenses. 
(x)  Liaise with DER in assisting the upload of the postworkshop statement and ensure 
that workshop materials are ready for publication on the ADB website. 
(xi)  Prepare a master list and compile all final print and electronic versions of regional 
TA reports, speeches, workshop presentations, and handouts. 
(xii)  Provide support on regional TA-related activities in its daily operations and perform 
other related tasks which may arise during consultancy.  
 
E.  Knowledge Products 
 
  1.  Background and Objectives 
 
16.  The Asia and Pacific region is experiencing rapid economic growth, resulting in increased 
energy demand. According to estimates, total world energy demand is expected to grow from 
7,261 million tons of oil equivalent (mtoe) to 17,095 mtoe in 2030. The corresponding financial 
requirement is around $21 billion. Such rapid growth in demand will need a judicious review of 
options and planning. As far as the electricity sector is concerned, coal-based power generation 
will account for about 80% of the total electricity generation in 2030. Such increased use of coal 
has unsustainable effects on the climate. Carbon dioxide emissions have already reached high 
levels and their effect on the climate is obvious. Some of these effects are abnormal weather 
patterns experienced recently, such as intense storms, severe and frequent droughts and floods, 
accelerated melting of glaciers, rises in sea level, higher frequency of forest fires, shortage of 
freshwater, threatened crop production and aquaculture, and higher incidence of heat-related and 
infectious diseases. Hence, there is a need to utilize coal in a more sustainable and efficient 
manner. Various cleaner technologies have been developed and some are in the process of 
development. The key issue will be to facilitate the path of technology transfer that is beneficial to 
all stakeholders. ADB is planning to commission a technical paper that highlights the effects of 
coal-based  power  generation,  its  economies,  need  for  new  technologies,  time  frame  for 
development, prospects of technology transfer, research costs, government policies and options 
for facilitating such transfer, and how multilateral agencies can help. 
 
17.  For a sustained and transparent electricity market, strict and fair regulatory mechanisms 
need to be in place as part of a phased reform and restructuring of the sector. Private sector 
participation will also increase to meet the growth in demand. In Asia, results of power sector 
reforms have been mixed—partially successful in some, and unsuccessful in others. It is clear that 
“one-size-fits–all” is not the right approach. Therefore, there is a need to provide DMCs with a 
history of the reforms, its development over time, costs, social and legal issues, lessons learned 
with case studies, and a list of options to achieve a transparent and fair electricity market which will 
focus on the benefits of the consumer. RSID will collaborate with other departments involved in 
governance,  especially  the  Office  of  the  General  Counsel  (OGC)  which  is  coordinating  and 
collaborating with RSID on various energy regulation projects. It is intended that issues identified 
and  discussed  in  this  paper  will  be  further  developed  and  researched  under  OGC’s  energy 
regulation knowledge products. The proposed technical note on energy regulation will include

Appendix 3    13 
review of the advances in energy sector regulation, progress achieved, lessons learned, and the 
way forward.  
 
18.  Advances in economic growth and associated increased energy demand have resulted in 
huge  investments  in  the  energy  sector.  Growth  potential  is  huge  and  DMCs  are  addressing 
increased energy needs with a variety of approaches, including technology transfer and innovative 
financing. Nevertheless, about 1 billion people of the Asia and Pacific region continue to live 
without  access  to  modern  forms  of  energy.  Many  DMCs  have  successfully  embarked  on 
addressing this important social need with some success but much needs to be done if the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  are  to  be  achieved.  A  number  of  options  are  being 
explored,  such  as  grid  extensions  and  off-grid  systems.  In  such  cases,  community-based 
organization setting up their own distributed off-grid system is an option that can be sustained and 
needs to be explored.  
 
19.  Taking the above aspects into consideration, ADB proposes to publish technical notes that 
will be made available to ADB and DMCs as knowledge products. They will be prepared by ADB 
along with experts or through energy research centers. Initially, in 2007, it is proposed to cover the 
following topics: 
 
(i)  Low Carbon Emitting Technologies in Electricity Generation – Options and Future  
  Outlook 
(ii)  Power Sector Regulation – Lessons Learned and The Way Forward 
(iii)  Community-Based Distributed Power Generation 
 
2.  Scope of Work 
 
20.  One international consultant with substantial background and knowledge in the field will be 
engaged in March 2007 for each of the three topics listed above for about 2 months each (totaling 
6 months). The document will be completed by July 2007.  
 
3.  Detailed Tasks 
 
21.  The terms of reference of the author will primarily consist of, but will not be limited to, the 
following: 
 
(i)  Preparation  of  and  finalization  of  a  tentative  annotated  outline  of  the  paper  in 
consultation with ADB within 1 week of the start of services. 
(ii)  Review of relevant literature and collection of and analysis of data and information. 
(iii)  Preparation of the document containing, among others, an overview of the energy 
situation in Asia and the Pacific region, analysis of key issues, relevant data and 
statistical tables, and key findings, conclusions and recommendations. 
(iv)  Providing drafts of the document in parts, as they are prepared, to seek feedback 
and comments from ADB. The entire document will also be submitted to ADB in 
draft form for final comments before finalization. 
(v)  Preparing the document containing a foreword, acknowledgment, table of contents, 
acronyms, glossary, and bibliography. 
(vi)  The final draft, incorporating comments from ADB, will be submitted within 1 week 
after receiving ADB’s comments. 
(vii)  Review of the manuscript, prior to printing of document. 
 
4.  Output 
 
22.  The length of the paper should be about 40–50 pages, with appendixes. A shorter version 
of  about  15  pages  should  also  be  provided.  This  will  probably  be  used  as  part  of  ADB’s 
forthcoming publication on energy outlook.
